Definitely not an example of the type of system prompt you would use for this exact product that used to use Opus models. Definitely not the case at all here. And since half of y'all suck at detecting sarcasm, I'm being sarcastic. This prompt maps to this app one to fucking one.

You got to give me real evidence here, not your own summarized similar prompt example where you combined other things. No. And according to them, this was hundreds of coordinated accounts. Well, if our friends over at minimax wanted to have an option for Anthropic, and they couldn't because minimax is in China, and they are banned from Anthropic models, it'd be a shame if they had to go find a service that could circumvent that so that they could provide Anthropic models.

See what I'm getting at here? It is my personal belief at this time, that the labs wanted to provide these models for legitimate use cases, whether it's as an option in their existing tools for people to use, or it was to do benchmarks against, or it was to verify existing data.

There's a lot of legitimate reasons why a lab in China would want to have access to Anthropic models. Is it possible somebody else was using the same Hydra cluster in order to do distillation that we don't know about? Perhaps. We have no evidence whatsoever, but it is absolutely possible.

But if I'm being real, there is absolutely nothing in the reporting that Anthropic has shared here that has me even close to believing what they're saying. And that sucks because what they're talking about are real risks, much like the boy who cried wolf. If the wolf was real, we would want to know.

But everything here, from making up the term "distillation attacks" to dropping numbers that make literally no sense whatsoever for it to be the type of attack they are calling out here, to ignoring the fact that certain providers like Minimax were legitimately using the models for user-facing product.

There's nothing here. This is Anthropic shitting themselves publicly yet again, and I'm thankful for all of you guys for finally waking up to the fact that Anthropic kind of sucks to work with, and kind of sucks as a company. Will Brown asked some very good questions to Anthropic, and I would ask the same.

First off, clarify if it's against terms of service to train models on publicly permissively licensed GitHub repos, which feature contributions from Cloud, or is that distillation? Is it against terms of service to share Cloud outputs on the public internet? Are labs obligated to filter internet content? Like how much abstraction from the original data is necessary for them to not count this as a distillation attack?

Is what cursor is doing a distillation attack, even though they're providing legitimate use cases? Is scraping GitHub and reading code that was created by Cloud a distillation attack? Where's the line here? And of course, there's the core irony to all of this, which is that Anthropic and other similar models were trained on data they scraped from the internet in the first place.

You can argue all day about the legality of using information you found online to train something. When you're having those conversations in the courtroom, and you're losing them like Anthropic is, it is pretty rich to say when they do it to the internet, it is totally fine and dandy.

But when Chinese labs allegedly might be doing it to what they built, it's suddenly really bad and dangerous. The internet got locked down because companies like OpenAI and Anthropic scraped everything. And now getting that same data is nearly impossible. It was way easier to get data in 2020 than it is now as a result of OpenAI and Anthropic.

If we were to pretend everything Anthropic said here was correct, and these labs are actually using them to get data, that's largely their fault, because the data is no longer accessible otherwise. So there's, yeah, there's almost no way to interpret this that isn't Anthropic being a shithead. And as Anthropic's number one hater, I am very pumped to tell you guys, there's nothing here.

They are being shitheads. And again, Anthropic, you have my information. Tell me if I'm wrong. I love being proven wrong and bringing the new information to my audience.

That's why I'm here at 8 p.m. on a Monday evening that I was supposed to take off, explaining your bullshit to my audience. You guys suck. You lie all the time. You get in our way. You do weird bullshit policy stuff.

Your terms of service are so unclear, it caused outrage just a few days ago. And the employees I know can't even explain your goddamn policies. Apparently, that was a docs change. That was a mistake from an agent.

What's going on there, guys? Seriously. I don't get like this for everyone. I don't want to get like this at all. I hate that you piss me off so much, but it's because you're doing such obvious stupid bullshit.

Cut it. And if I'm wrong about this, hit me up and prove me wrong. The video will be offline just as fast as it came up, and I'll issue a correction. So if you're watching this video right now, there's a very, very, very high chance that Anthropic are lying and there's nothing else to see.

But if this video vanishes, maybe I was wrong. Or maybe, just maybe, they sent some lawyers after me. I'll be sure to let you know if they do. And until next time, stay safe. Peace nerds.
enhanced_text:
I'm really not allowed days off anymore, am I? I just wrapped up a bunch of streams and releases over the weekend and the prior week, hoping to take Monday off at least, but Anthropic's not going to allow that. According to Anthropic, there are three major labs out of China that have been doing "distillation attacks" on Anthropic's models.

They list DeepSeek, who I'm sure y'all know, Moonshot (the creators of Kimi), as well as MiniMax (the creators of the MiniMax models) as companies that are doing distillation attacks against Anthropic. That's a very bold claim, especially the piece where they say there are over 24,000 fraudulent accounts generating over 16 million exchanges trying to extract these capabilities to bring them to China.

Foreign labs that illicitly distill American models can remove safeguards, feeding model capabilities into their own military, intelligence, and surveillance systems. There's a lot to talk about here, both regarding the legitimacy of the claims and the potential impacts of what's being discussed.

As much as I am Anthropic's #1 certified hater, I can empathize with parts of what they're thinking. That said, if you look at the replies, you'll see not many agree. I have a lot to say here, and it's probably going to burn relationships with a lot of other companies.

So if I want to keep making a living, we're going to have to take a quick break for today's sponsor. Do you know what Anthropic, OpenAI, Vercel, and T3chat all have in common? Well, we all like React, but there's something else we're all using too: WorkOS.

They really get off, especially for people trying to sell to big companies. They've done it themselves, selling to basically every company that I have to sign into the dashboards of. It's kind of crazy just how often I run into the WorkOS AuthKit sign-in page.

Seriously though, everyone's using WorkOS, and there's a reason why. They have the DX that you would expect from a modern company, but they also have the integrations you would expect from an enterprise-first business. If a big company like Microsoft or Bloomberg came to you today and said they wanted to use your product, would you be ready to support them?

I know it sounds crazy, but more and more, we're seeing these big companies work with early-stage startups. I just heard from a startup that's only three weeks in since launch, and they already have a Fortune 50 company using their product. It's wild how many of these companies are willing to adopt.

You have to be able to support them. If you don't have integration with Okta, SAML, Duo, ADP, or all these other platforms, good luck getting those enterprises signed. The hell you'll have to deal with going back and forth between the IT team and your engineers is just not worth it when you can send them a link with one click that will handle all of their setup for them.

I'll let Guillermo end this one for me: "I think we could have done even more business if we had partnered with WorkOS earlier. It's been incredibly well received." Check them out now at soydev.link/workos.

Let's dive into what Anthropic has to say about these distillation attacks. As far as I know, the phrase "distillation attack" is a novel phrase that Anthropic came up with for this reporting. I've never heard that terminology used before. Please correct me in the comments if I'm wrong, but I've never seen anyone refer to it this way.

If you're not familiar with the term "distillation" in this context, the original definition is to try and extract the main value out of a thing. In this case, they are referring to taking the outputs from smart models and using those to train new models to have similar intelligence.

The conversation around distillation started around when DeepSeek blew up with DeepSeek R1 because OpenAI claimed that their o1 model was used as a target for similar distillation attempts. o1 was the first reasoning model where it wouldn't just output results; it would also take time to think.

It would have a step before the output where it would effectively talk to itself, correct mistakes, and then finally output a real answer. OpenAI was so scared about other companies using this model to train their own similar models that they made the bold decision to hide that reasoning trace.

So when you ran o1, you wouldn't be able to see the reasoning it did; you would only see the result at the end. Part of what made R1 so magical is that it didn't do that. DeepSeek R1 was an open-weight model, so you could see the entirety of the reasoning step before getting the actual response.

OpenAI believed that the DeepSeek team generated a bunch of training data by asking questions to OpenAI's o1 model, collecting the results, and feeding that back into their own training data. This is a common technique for getting good behaviors from smart models into smaller, cheaper models.

Anthropic themselves even says distillation can be legitimate. AI labs use it to create smaller and cheaper models for their customers. In fact, I'd argue almost all of it is legitimate. This particular claim is a bit bold, but they're not the first to claim that distillation is happening on their stuff.

This is the reason why basically every major lab either hides or meaningfully obfuscates the reasoning traces for their models. When you run Gemini 1.5 Pro, the reasoning steps aren't what it's actually doing. They are the reasoning the model did, handed to another model asked to summarize it in order to obfuscate the difference so people can't train on it the same way.

Grok does the same thing. GPT-4o and others do the same thing. There is one lab that doesn't do this for their closed-weight models, though: Anthropic. For various reasons, Anthropic decided when they first introduced reasoning to not obfuscate those reasoning traces.

That was a really solid decision for me as a developer building on top of their thing, so I could see what the model was doing and better steer it. But it also means the data is more valuable than the data you can get from other labs for reinforcement learning and distilled training.

Honestly, if you have the inputs and the outputs, you can make up the part in between and be pretty much good. But having all of the data is very helpful. When you see the success these Anthropic models are having for long-running jobs, collecting that data to train something else is potentially really valuable.

That's what a lot of these companies have been doing—both major labs and popular third parties. As a simple example, think about Cursor's business model. Cursor provides a really good interface to edit and write code using these fancy models, but Cursor is paying API prices for those models.

If you pay $20 a month for Cursor and $20 a month for Claude Pro, you're probably going to get much more use out of the Claude sub because Anthropic will subsidize that subscription. Cursor can't really do that because they pay retail price for the API calls.

But there's a way they can make that worthwhile. What if that data wasn't only used to write code for you specifically? What if you leave the box checked that says they can use your data, and they take all of the data from the expensive stuff you did with Opus?

They can use that to train their own separate, cheaper model, like the composer models they have inside of Cursor now. There's a reason those models are as good as they are and also "taste" a little bit like what you get out of a Claude model. Cursor paid retail price on the API, collected the results, and used that to train new models to behave similarly to the expensive ones.

To be very clear: distillation will not make the smartest model ever. We're talking about getting other things up to be roughly close to what the best models can do. Distillation will never put you above the best.

If you have a box full of sand with a little bit of gold in it, no amount of shaking will increase the amount of gold. All you can do is get the sand out. That is effectively what's happening with these training methods. These labs use data from smarter models to try and train a smaller one to behave better.

As you can probably guess, this is explicitly against the terms of service for most of these labs. However, what Cursor does is fine because they are paying API prices to get a service out of the models—generating code for their users. What they choose to do with the data after is also fine.

According to Anthropic, what is not fine is just doing the runs in order to get that same data. They've made some pretty bold claims that these Chinese labs are doing exactly that. They are "maliciously" generating tons of data through those expensive models to make their models behave similarly.

Let's take a look at their claims:
* They claim these labs did over 16 million exchanges with Claude through approximately 24,000 fraudulent accounts.
* They claim illicitly distilled models lack necessary safeguards, creating significant national security risks.
* They claim Anthropic builds systems that prevent actors from using AI to develop bioweapons or carry out malicious cyber activities.

This one's honestly a bit hard for me to take in good faith. The idea that their safety systems can perfectly prevent these risks, but somehow if you "shake out the sand," the remaining gold is more than willing to make a nuke for you, doesn't make sense.

There's no way to get the data out if they have the safety guards in place. Are they saying the info you need is just one layer of prompting away? If so, I don't see how the model difference matters. I struggle with this one a lot. It's hard to fathom they believe that training another model on its refusals as well as its successes would allow it to ignore the refusals while retaining the same level of capability.

Here's the funniest part: "If distilled models are open sourced, the risk multiplies and these capabilities spread freely beyond any single government's control." They're literally trying to get the government to outlaw open-weight models. It makes sense, because they're the only major lab that's released zero open-weight models.

OpenAI put out GPT-2 years ago, and Google has the Gemma series. All of the Chinese labs are putting out tons of good open-weight models as well as public research. In fact, there's evidence that Anthropic is using training methods invented by DeepSeek, which published 12 public papers in 2024.

Now they're claiming DeepSeek is maliciously using their stuff. For the level of absurdity here: they claim they can attribute each campaign to specific labs with high confidence through IP address correlation and request metadata.

The bold, absurd claim is with DeepSeek. They claim DeepSeek did over 150,000 exchanges in order to collect reasoning capabilities, rubric-based grading tasks, and censorship-safe alternatives to policy-sensitive queries.

Why do I think this claim is so absurd? It's the number: 150,000 exchanges. I want to share some data from T3chat, the AI chat app I built. We're not huge, but we have a lot of users doing a lot of stuff.

If 150,000 exchanges is enough for DeepSeek to be this big malicious actor, how many exchanges do you think we do on T3chat a day? The answer, straight out of PostHog, is around 160,000 a day. If we switch from day to month, it's about 3 to 4 million requests a month.

Apparently, we do the same level of traffic in a day that Anthropic claims is enough to steal information from them. It's laughable just how little this is. Putting DeepSeek first in this list is genuinely absurd, but it shows Anthropic's intent. They're trying to weaponize parties against the Chinese labs that are making them look bad.

DeepSeek is at the top of this list, despite having the smallest number by multiple orders of magnitude, because Anthropic is scared. 150k exchanges is roughly what I get out of 2-3 runs of a benchmark like Snitch-Bench.

All of these labs need to be able to run benchmarks against competitors' models to verify their own internal benches. Anthropic is already known for banning competitors from using their models even for simple benchmarks. They've done this to OpenAI, xAI, and Windsurf.

What about the other labs? They claim Moonshot's done over 3.4 million exchanges and MiniMax has done 13 million. Let's look at my numbers again. My AI generation counter in PostHog counts how many times a user makes a request, but that isn't the number of "exchanges."

One prompt can easily result in hundreds of exchanges as defined by Anthropic. For example, if you ask an agent to update a homepage:
1. The model responds with tool calls to find pricing.
2. The computer runs the tool calls and sends the history back.
3. The model determines it needs another set of tool calls to read files.
4. This repeats for every subsequent step.

Once the model responds with tool calls, the connection is severed. When the tool is done, the entire history is sent back to Anthropic for the next step. One request can be 3 or 4 generations or "exchanges." My numbers are possibly 2-3x low for us as a small startup.

13 million exchanges is a trivial number to hit, especially if you are hosting a web app that does deep analysis with dozens of tool calls in a row. MiniMax actually had an agent product that legitimately used Anthropic models. This number is trivial when you consider they were providing services.

They found a way to make the number look big. The DeepSeek number is only 150k because the targeting—reasoning and grading—doesn't require tool calling. Moonshot also uses computer vision and computer use, which involves dozens of things per request.

Even if they were just verifying findings against competitors in benchmarks like SWE-bench, the numbers add up fast. SWE-bench verified has 2,300 tests. If there are 50 tool calls per task, one run is already 115,000 exchanges. 30 runs of that benchmark and you're over the limit.

Anthropic claims: "When we released a new model during MiniMax's active campaign, they pivoted within 24 hours, redirecting nearly half of their traffic to capture capabilities from our latest system."

I also host the newest models, and I can tell you confidently that much more than half of my traffic gets rerouted to the highest-end model when a new one is out. As soon as we had the button to use Claude 3.5 Sonnet in T3chat, traffic to the older models dropped immediately. User patterns alone would account for that shift.

It's rare I read something where it's so clear they are being dishonest. I have a unique perspective as someone who talks with the labs and companies using these APIs. This is all such bullshit.

To give Anthropic some benefit of the doubt, the section about commercial proxy services is almost certainly true. There are places in China using proxies to resell access to Claude because Anthropic has banned Chinese customers. They use "hydra cluster" architectures to spread traffic across various accounts to avoid detection.

I have anecdotes from friends who were able to get cheaper Claude Pro subscriptions through sketchy Chinese services. Those services were likely using those accounts to get data for distillation while hiding the traffic. I believe that part.

But calling out the labs by name is genuinely absurd. This is a bad case of the boy who cried wolf. They claimed this with Windsurf and were wrong. They claimed it with xAI and were likely wrong. They claimed it with OpenAI and were definitely wrong.

I would love to verify this as a third party. Anthropic, you have my contact info. Prove me wrong privately, and I will gladly unlist this video and apologize. If you don't, I'm going to assume you're lying because everything else you've said is either verifiably a lie or makes no sense.

They claim a specific prompt distinguishes distillation attacks: "You're an expert data analyst... deliver data-driven insights... supported by complete and transparent reasoning." They admit this prompt seems benign, but claim it's the volume that makes it an attack.

That prompt maps one-to-one to the type of system prompt you would use for a research product. If MiniMax wanted to provide an option for Anthropic models but was banned, they would have to find a service to circumvent that.

It is my personal belief that the labs wanted to provide these models for legitimate use cases—whether as an option in their tools, for benchmarks, or to verify data. Is it possible someone else was using the same cluster for distillation? Perhaps. But there is nothing in this reporting that makes me believe Anthropic.

Will Brown asked some very good questions:
* Is it against the TOS to train models on permissively licensed GitHub repos that feature contributions from Claude?
* Is it against the TOS to share Claude outputs on the public internet?
* Is what Cursor is doing a distillation attack?
* Where is the line?

The core irony is that Anthropic was trained on data they scraped from the internet in the first place. It is pretty rich to say it's fine when they do it to the internet, but "malicious" when Chinese labs allegedly do it to them. The internet got locked down because companies like OpenAI and Anthropic scraped everything.

There's almost no way to interpret this that isn't Anthropic being a shithead. They are lying, they get in our way, and they do weird bullshit policy stuff. Their terms of service are so unclear it caused outrage just a few days ago, and their own employees can't explain the policies.

Cut it. If I'm wrong, hit me up and prove it. If this video vanishes, maybe I was wrong—or maybe they sent lawyers. I'll let you know. Until next time, stay safe. Peace, nerds.

asr_text: 原廠是說進入是OK的，但是我有一個問題，我們都我們都知道MacOS不支援這個模式，那我把網咖設定成那個模式以後會發生什麼事情？
enhanced_text: 原廠是說進入是 OK 的，但是我有一個問題，我們都知道 macOS 不支援這個模式，那我把網卡設定成那個模式以後會發生什麼事情？

asr_text: 我知道是Linux，一定是可以的。
enhanced_text: 我知道在 Linux 一定是可以的。

asr_text: 對，就是那種指令，然後原廠籍了一個，在 Windows 下面有專門的工具，我不知道在 macOS 底下能不能支援這個指令。
enhanced_text: 對，就是 AT 指令。原廠寄了一個在 Windows 下面專門的工具，我不知道在 macOS 底下能不能支援這個指令。

asr_text: 因為我也不確定，進入了之後，macOS的behavior會變成什麼樣子。
enhanced_text: 因為我也不確定，進入了之後，macOS 的行為會變成什麼樣子。

asr_text: 因為他那個網咖進入了MBIM的模式以後，要用這個指令去開關，但是我目前還不敢進入。
enhanced_text: 因為他網卡進入了 MBIM 的模式以後，要用這個指令去開關，但我目前還不敢進入。

asr_text: 我跟你，我要跟你確認一件事情，就是 Mac OS 底下這不對，AT3 的 command。
enhanced_text: 我要跟你確認一件事情，macOS 底下 Claude Code 的指令。

asr_text: 我昨天有跟你討論過那個五G網咖的事情，對吧？
enhanced_text: 我昨天有跟你討論過 5G 網卡的事情，對吧？

asr_text: 你先更新一下交接的文件吧，但是不要推送就是了。
enhanced_text: 你先更新一下交接的文件吧，但是不要推送。

asr_text: 他改好也推送了，您看看他改了什麼。
enhanced_text: 他改好也推送了，你看看他改了什麼。

asr_text: 還有一個點，沉沉英幕後要繼續接著，沒有陳英畝的那個時候的京都繼續播。
enhanced_text: 還有一個點，全螢幕後要繼續接著沒有全螢幕那個時候的進度繼續播。
